explanation:
Why each symbol is needed to check the MISRA rule ("A function parameter should not be modified") for OS_API_Teardown:

- OS_DeleteAllObjects: This is a direct callee in OS_API_Teardown. To be confident that OS_API_Teardown does not modify any function parameters (or local variables that are actually parameters inlined/forwarded), inspect the prototype/definition of OS_DeleteAllObjects to confirm it takes no parameters or to see how any parameters are passed/used. If OS_DeleteAllObjects had been called with local variables that are function parameters of OS_API_Teardown, that would be relevant; the symbol must be checked.

- OS_ApplicationShutdown: Direct callee; OS_API_Teardown calls OS_ApplicationShutdown(true). Inspecting its prototype verifies the type of the formal parameter(s) (e.g., whether a pointer is involved) and ensures OS_API_Teardown does not modify any of its own parameters when preparing arguments. Also review its behavior for completeness (even though the MISRA rule concerns modification of formals inside a function, confirming the argument passing is safe is necessary).

- OS_ApplicationShutdown_Impl: This is the implementation-level routine invoked by OS_ApplicationShutdown (per call graph). Including the Impl symbol lets the analyzer see the actual function that receives the parameter(s) and verify there is no indirect manipulation of any parameter variables that could have originated from OS_API_Teardown.

- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler: Appears in the static call graph as a callee reachable from OS_API_Teardown (and used by the OS_* wrappers). Include this symbol because it may be invoked indirectly by the callee chain (stubs/handlers). Checking its prototype and implementation ensures there is no unexpected usage that would require OS_API_Teardown to set up or modify parameter variables (or pointers) prior to invocation.

Note: OS_API_Teardown itself has no parameters (void), so it cannot directly violate the stated MISRA rule. The listed symbols are the minimal set of direct callees / immediate implementations the next analyst should inspect to confirm there are no indirect parameter-related issues (for example, if any argument came from a parameter of OS_API_Teardown or if the call chain relied on modifying a caller-provided pointer variable).
